Expectation1: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation1: A client has an inquiry about a specific line item on their most recent invoice.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story:
I was in the middle of reviewing spreadsheets when my phone buzzed—a client, anxious about a confusing line item on their latest invoice, needed clarification right away. I knew I had to call them back and walk through the numbers, but I glanced at the clock and felt my stomach twist. I had just enough time to get to the polling station before it closed. Voting was important to me, and I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss it.

When I arrived, the election official frowned at my registration. There was a mismatch, and I’d have to fill out a provisional ballot form. She explained the process, emphasizing I had only ten minutes before the station closed. My phone vibrated again—the client, calling back, probably growing more frustrated by the minute. I felt torn. As an accountant, I was expected to be responsive and clear, especially with financial concerns. As a voter, I was expected to follow the official’s instructions and complete the process properly. My mind raced, caught between the urgent needs of my client and my civic responsibility, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in on me at once.
